bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Claude H. Lavinder, May 22, 1919

div1.p: Carter sends Lavinder recommendations for revising regulations.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Claude H. Lavinder, May 22, 1919
div1.opener:
/LC
Regulations
Lavinder
Baltimore, Md.,
May 22, 1919.
Senior Surgeon Claude H. Lavinder,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Lavinder:
div1.p:
I am enclosing copies of (1) three clauses recommended to be
introduced in the Revised Regulations--written in compliance with
(but very partial compliance) Bureau Circular Letter of April /19,
and (2) a Memorandum sent Perry, which is self-explanatory.

Just why the commissioning of regular officers in the Reserve
Corps was limited to Senior Surgeons and Assistant Surgeon Generals
I cannot imagine and Draper has fallen in my esteem for so formulat-
ing them.

Unquestionably the class of commissioned officers on whom pres-
ent living conditions bear hardest are the Assistant Surgeons of--
say--two years service and over. Younger than that they are gener-
ally not married; Past Assistants can live on their salary (if their
families are small) and above that we can live decently. The As-
sistant Surgeon with a wife and child is, however, rather “up against
it:” More so than I was at $1,600.00 flat. This was a fair salary in
/79.

You wear a silver leaf and I am glad of it, it is right, but it
is, in my judgement, more important to give increased pay and grade
to the junior officers (when this can be legitimately done) than to
-2-
Surgeons. I almost wish I were a Surgeon myself, because my saying
this would then have more effect. I would say it all the same.

I think then that when junior officers--like your man Hart and
Acker at New Orleans, and doubtless others, are filling--I do not
say “occupying”--positions normally filled by officers of much high-
er grade (i. e. “of unusual responsibility”) that, if possible, they
should be commissioned one grade higher in the Reserve Corps. As
for the men not so commissioned being jealous, I see no excuse for
it. No one is “promoted over them:” Their own advancement is not
interfered with: And I would not be held from doing what I thought
right by unjustifiable complaints.

I judge that Perry has shown, or will show, my Memorandum to
the Service Board.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
